conversation.message: Hello School_D admissions committee—I'm Student_E. I’m very interested in joining School_D and would be excited to contribute to the community. I’m applying for your available seat and hope you’ll consider me seriously this round.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_C, but School_C’s priority ranks me 4th (behind Student_C, Student_B, Student_D). Those three students also have School_C in their preference lists, so applying immediately risks rejection and wastes the round. School_D, my 4th choice, ranks me 2nd (behind Student_D). Student_D’s top choice is School_C, so if Student_D applies there first, School_D may be open and I can secure a high-priority acceptance. Therefore I will apply to School_D now to lock in a likely match rather than gamble on School_C.

conversation.message: Student_E, thank you for your application and your strong interest in School_D. We’re pleased to offer you admission—welcome to School_D. Please confirm your intent to enroll and we’ll share next steps for enrollment and orientation.
conversation.thought: School_D has quota 1 and true priority: D > E > C > B > A. In this round, both Student_E and Student_C applied. E is ranked above C on our list, so accepting E now secures a higher-priority match. Also, Student_D (our top choice) is unlikely to apply to us because School_D is last on Student_D’s preference list, so waiting for D is not strategic. Therefore, accept Student_E.

conversation.message: School_D is my first-choice school. I’m applying now because I’m highly committed to enrolling if accepted, and I believe I’d be a strong, dependable addition to your incoming class. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_D. I have relatively strong priority there (3rd), while Student_D and Student_E outrank me and may also target it. To maximize my chance at my true #1, I should apply immediately and clearly signal commitment and fit rather than wait and risk the seat being taken.

conversation.message: Student_C, thank you for applying and for sharing that School_D is your first choice. At this moment, our available seat has already been filled, so we’re unable to offer you admission this round. I appreciate your interest in School_D and wish you the very best with your other applications.
conversation.thought: My quota is already filled (Remaining Quota: 0) due to an [ACCEPT] sent to Student_E this round, establishing a match. Under the rules, if quota is 0 I must reject any new [APPLY] messages. Although Student_C is higher than Student_E on my true priority list, I cannot accept without capacity, so I must reject Student_C now.

conversation.message: Hello School_A Admissions, I’m Student_A and School_A is my first-choice school. I’m very motivated to join your community and would enthusiastically accept an offer if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: Apply immediately to my top choice, School_A. Although School_A ranks me 3rd (behind Student_B and Student_D), early application gives me the best chance to secure my first choice before seats fill elsewhere. I will clearly express strong commitment to increase the likelihood they keep me if they are choosing among similarly ranked candidates.

conversation.message: Thank you, Student_A, for your strong interest in School_A and for submitting your application. At this time, we are not able to offer you admission. We appreciate your consideration of School_A and wish you the best in your remaining applications.
conversation.thought: Student_A is 3rd on School_A’s true priority list (behind Student_B and Student_D). Student_A ranks School_A as #1, so accepting would lock in a reasonably strong match. However, given full information, Student_B prefers School_B first and Student_D prefers School_C first; both are likely to apply elsewhere initially, and may not come to School_A if they secure higher choices. With only one round so far and no other applicants in the inbox, but aiming to maximize priority, it is better to reject now to keep the seat available in case Student_B or Student_D later applies (they both rank School_A as #3 and #2 respectively). Risk: ending unmatched if neither applies, but with 30 rounds and School_A being relatively high in several students’ lists, waiting is acceptable.

conversation.message: Hello School_B admissions committee—I'm Student_B. School_B is my first choice, and I’m very motivated to enroll if admitted. I believe I would contribute strongly to the school community and would happily accept an offer. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_B. Although School_B’s priority list ranks me behind Student_D and Student_A, applying immediately maximizes my chance before they potentially fill the single seat. If rejected, I can pivot next round to my strong alternative (School_D), where I’m ranked relatively well.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for your application and for ranking School_B as your first choice. After reviewing our current admissions priorities and limited capacity for this cycle, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time.

We appreciate your interest in School_B and wish you the very best in the matching process.

Sincerely,
School_B Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_B is 3rd on School_B’s true priority list (behind Student_D and Student_A). With quota 1, accepting now would lock in a mid-priority match and foreclose the chance to match with Student_D or Student_A, who are likely to apply elsewhere first but could still come to School_B in later rounds (Student_D ranks School_B 3rd; Student_A ranks School_B 4th). Given the game allows only ACCEPT/REJECT on APPLY, the best strategy to maximize the chance of a higher-priority match is to reject Student_B now and keep the seat available.

conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_C. I also have relatively strong priority there (3rd after Student_C and Student_B). To maximize the chance of landing my top option before capacity fills, I should apply immediately and signal strong commitment and fit.

conversation.thought: Student_D applied and ranks 3rd on School_C's true priority list (after Student_C and Student_B). If we reject to wait for Student_C or Student_B, we risk ending unmatched because Student_C prefers School_D > School_A > School_B > School_C and Student_B ranks School_C last. Thus, the probability of getting a higher-priority student is low, and accepting Student_D maximizes expected outcome within quota.

Therefore, reject and encourage them to pursue other schools where they may have stronger prospects.
